query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
1 Poi fummo dentro al soglio de la porta 2 che ’l mal amor de l’anime disusa, 3 perché fa parer dritta la via torta,
4 sonando la senti’ esser richiusa; 5 e s’io avesse li occhi vòlti ad essa, 6 qual fora stata al fallo degna scusa?
7 Noi salavam per una pietra fessa, 8 che si moveva e d’una e d’altra parte, 9 sì come l’onda che fugge e s’appressa.
query.result:
**English:**
1 Then we were inside the threshold of the gate 2 that evil love of abandoned souls, 3 because it makes the crooked path seem straight,
4 and I heard it being closed behind me; 5 and if I had turned my eyes to it, 6 what excuse would have been worthy for my fault?
7 We climbed up a cracked stone, 8 which moved from one side to the other, 9 like a wave that flees and approaches.
**Cornish:**
1 Wosa henna y’n oen dhe’n fordh a’n fordh 2 henna kammledh drog a enevalow treghys, 3 rag henna a wra kov an fordh gamm dhe hweghel,
4 ow klevos henna ow tos dhe serry. 5 Ha pan gensen ow treylys ow lagha dhe’n fordh, 6 pyw a vijen dhe’n feth deg tus a-rag?
7 Ni a sevel orth dhe garrek towlek, 8 a-droadha ow dhe unn tu ha’n aral, 9 kepar ha tonn a dheu ha dhe jun.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
10 «Qui si conviene usare un poco d’arte», 11 cominciò ’l duca mio, «in accostarsi 12 or quinci, or quindi al lato che si parte».
query.result:
**English:**
10 “Here it is necessary to use a little skill,” 11 my leader began, “in moving closer 12 now to this side, now to that, as it moves away.”
**Cornish:**
10 “Ama yma yma hy a-dhegemma unn lyther vyth,” 11 a leveris ow duga, “yn dalleth dhe junya 12 a-lemmyn ama, a-lemmyn ena, dhe’n tu a dheu.”

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
13 E questo fece i nostri passi scarsi, 14 tanto che pria lo scemo de la luna 15 rigiunse al letto suo per ricorcarsi,
16 che noi fossimo fuor di quella cruna; 17 ma quando fummo liberi e aperti 18 sù dove il monte in dietro si rauna,
19 ïo stancato e amendue incerti 20 di nostra via, restammo in su un piano 21 solingo più che strade per diserti.
query.result:
**English:**
13 And this made our steps slow, 14 so much so that the waning moon 15 reached its bed to set again,
16 before we were out of that narrow passage; 17 but when we were free and in the open, 18 up where the mountain draws back,
19 I, weary, and both of us uncertain 20 of our way, stopped on a plain 21 more solitary than roads through deserts.
**Cornish:**
13 Ha henna a wrug ni passyow skar, 14 kemmys na kyns an loer a’n loer 15 a junyas dhe’y gwely dhe hweghel orth,
16 kyns henna ni a vijen dhe’n kuntel; 17 mes pan oen ni frank ha apert 18 wartha y’n menydh a wra dhe’n keffrys,
19 ow, skuys, ha ni oll anpubsur, 20 a’gan fordh, ni a sevel orth wartha plan 21 solek ages tra fordhow dre deserthow.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
28 Là sù non eran mossi i piè nostri anco, 29 quand’ io conobbi quella ripa intorno 30 che dritto di salita aveva manco,
31 esser di marmo candido e addorno 32 d’intagli sì, che non pur Policleto, 33 ma la natura lì avrebbe scorno.
query.result:
**English:**
28 There our feet had not yet moved, 29 when I recognized that surrounding cliff 30 which had a path of ascent on the left,
31 to be of white marble and adorned 32 with carvings such that not only Polykleitos, 33 but Nature herself would have been put to shame there.
**Cornish:**
28 Awnedha nag esa movys agensow tramor, 29 pan wrugav vy an repa henna a-dro, 30 esa gans dhymmyn dhe bennans dhe'n klew,
31 dhe bos marbel gwyn ha perthys 32 gans ker瘘ys, marnas Polykleitos hep, 33 mes an termyn honan a via skorryes.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
34 L’angel che venne in terra col decreto 35 de la molt’ anni lagrimata pace, 36 ch’aperse il ciel del suo lungo divieto,
37 dinanzi a noi pareva sì verace 38 quivi intagliato in un atto soave, 39 che non sembiava imagine che tace.
query.result:
**English:**
34 The angel who came to earth with the decree 35 of the peace wept for many years, 36 who opened heaven from its long interdict,
37 appeared before us so lifelike there, 38 carved in a gentle pose, 39 that it did not seem to be a silent image.
**Cornish:**
34 An el a dheuth dhe'n bys gans an dekret 35 a'n peth moy a vledhynny gans degyans, 36 a dhyskudhas nevon a'y hir voygans,
37 a-rag dhe'n klew a omdhiskwedhas mar gwir 38 ena ker瘘ys yn onan gwrians melyon, 39 na omdhiskwedhas mar delwedh mudh.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
46 «Non tener pur ad un loco la mente», 47 disse ’l dolce maestro, che m’avea 48 da quella parte onde ’l cuore ha la gente.
query.result:
**English:**
46 “Do not keep your mind fixed on one place alone,” 47 said the gentle master, who was on that side 48 where people have their heart.
**Cornish:**
46 “Na wra dhe'gas moy dhe onan le, 47 leveris an mester melyon, a'm esa 48 dhe'n tu-ma dhe'n kalon an dus.”

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
49 Per ch’i’ mi mossi col viso, e vedea 50 di retro da Maria, da quella costa 51 onde m’era colui che mi movea,
52 un’altra storia ne la roccia imposta; 53 per ch’io varcai Virgilio, e fe’mi presso, 54 acciò che fosse a li occhi miei disposta.
query.result:
**English:**
49 Therefore I moved with my gaze, and saw 50 behind Mary, on that side 51 where was he who moved me,
52 another story depicted on the rock; 53 therefore I passed Virgil and drew near, 54 so that it would be clear to my eyes.
**Cornish:**
49 Rag henna y’m mos vy gans vy golwg, ha’m gwelas 50 a-dhyworth Maria, dhe'n tu-ma henna 51 dhe'n esa henna a'm movas,
52 onan istori arall war an garrek; 53 rag henna yth ethas orth Virgilio, ha’m wrug vy dhe'n klew, 54 rag henna a via kler dhe'm lagha.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
55 Era intagliato lì nel marmo stesso 56 lo carro e ’ buoi, traendo l’arca santa, 57 per che si teme officio non commesso.
query.result:
**English:**
55 There was carved there in the marble itself 56 the cart and the oxen, drawing the holy ark, 57 for which reason one fears an unauthorized task.
**Cornish:**
55 Esa ker瘘ys ena y’n marbel honan 56 an kar ha’n oen, ow tosa an arka sans, 57 rag henna yth omdhiskwedh offis na omdhiskwedhys.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
58 Dinanzi parea gente; e tutta quanta, 59 partita in sette cori, a’ due mie’ sensi 60 faceva dir l’un ‘No’, l’altro ‘Sì, canta’.
query.result:
**English:**
58 In front appeared people; and all of them, 59 divided into seven choirs, made 60 one of my senses say ‘No’, the other ‘Yes, sing’.
**Cornish:**
58 A-rag omdhiskwedhas dus; ha oll an dus, 59 rannys yn seyth kor, dhe'm dew syns 60 a wrug leverel onan ‘Na’, an arall ‘Ya, kan’.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
61 Similemente al fummo de li ’ncensi 62 che v’era imaginato, li occhi e ’l naso 63 e al sì e al no discordi fensi.
query.result:
**English:**
61 Similarly, the smoke of the incense 62 that was depicted there made my eyes and nose 63 disagree with the yes and the no.
**Cornish:**
61 Yn keth, dhe'n mwg a'n ensens 62 a esa ymajinys ena, an lagha ha'n fron 63 dhe'n ‘ya’ ha'n ‘na’ a wrug omdhiskwedhel.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
64 Lì precedeva al benedetto vaso, 65 trescando alzato, l’umile salmista, 66 e più e men che re era in quel caso.
query.result:
**English:**
64 There, dancing and uplifted, the humble psalmist 65 preceded the blessed vessel, 66 and in that situation he was more and less than a king.
**Cornish:**
64 Ena a leveris a-rag an les bennak, 65 ow dansa ow sevel, an salmyst isel, 66 ha moy ha le a vri yn an kas henna.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
67 Di contra, effigïata ad una vista 68 d’un gran palazzo, Micòl ammirava 69 sì come donna dispettosa e trista.
query.result:
**English:**
67 Opposite, depicted in a scene 68 of a great palace, Michal looked on 69 like a disdainful and sorrowful woman.
**Cornish:**
67 A-dhyworth, ymajinys yn onan gweles 68 a onan palas bras, Mykol a omdhiskwedhas 69 mar benen dispris ha trist.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
70 I’ mossi i piè del loco dov’ io stava, 71 per avvisar da presso un’altra istoria, 72 che di dietro a Micòl mi biancheggiava.
query.result:
**English:**
70 I moved my feet from the place where I was standing, 71 to learn more about another story, 72 which was gleaming white behind Michal.
**Cornish:**
70 Y’m mosas y’m peow ow’n le mayth o’m sevas, 71 rag treylya moy ow bys vyth istori, 72 o’th o’n keffrys dhe Micoel o’m gwynnhe.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
79 Intorno a lui parea calcato e pieno 80 di cavalieri, e l’aguglie ne l’oro 81 sovr’ essi in vista al vento si movieno.
query.result:
**English:**
79 Around him seemed pressed and packed 80 a host of knights, and the eagles in gold 81 above them seemed to move in the wind.
**Cornish:**
79 A-dro dhe’y esa o’th esa gwaskys ha leun 80 gans varghas, ha’n erow yn an our 81 a-ugh dhe’y penn a skoodhas yn an gwyns.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
94 Colui che mai non vide cosa nova 95 produsse esto visibile parlare, 96 novello a noi perché qui non si trova.
query.result:
**English:**
94 He who never saw anything new 95 produced this visible speech, 96 new to us because it is not found here.
**Cornish:**
94 An neb a welas vyth tra nowydh 95 a wrug an lavarow gweladow ma, 96 nowydh dhe nyn gan nag eus yma.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
97 Mentr’ io mi dilettava di guardare 98 l’imagini di tante umilitadi, 99 e per lo fabbro loro a veder care,
100 «Ecco di qua, ma fanno i passi radi», 101 mormorava il poeta, «molte genti: 102 questi ne ’nvïeranno a li alti gradi».
query.result:
**English:**
97 While I was delighting in gazing at 98 the images of so much humility, 99 and in seeing them cherished by their maker,
100 “Look over here, but they are taking slow steps,” 101 the poet was murmuring, “many people: 102 these will send us to the high ranks”.
**Cornish:**
97 Pan o’m delythys yn gwelwel 98 an imajys a gemmys humiliteth, 99 ha rag an gwrer a welas kar,
100 “Sel, a-dhyworth, mes yma y’gansi pasow rad,” 101 a leveris an bardh, “mons a dusma: 102 hemma a’n kas dhe’n ughel rad.”

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
103 Li occhi miei, ch’a mirare eran contenti 104 per veder novitadi ond’ e’ son vaghi, 105 volgendosi ver’ lui non furon lenti.
query.result:
**English:**
103 My eyes, which were content to gaze 104 at seeing new things for which they are eager, 105 were not slow in turning towards him.
**Cornish:**
103 Y’m lagha, ow a’n welas o’th esa lowen 104 rag gwelwel nowydh, ow’s yns esa kegis, 105 na’n esa dalleth dhe dro dhe’y.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
106 Non vo’ però, lettor, che tu ti smaghi 107 di buon proponimento per udire 108 come Dio vuol che ’l debito si paghi.
query.result:
**English:**
106 But I do not want you, reader, to lose heart 107 from your good intentions on hearing 108 how God wants debts to be paid.
**Cornish:**
106 Mes nyns yw y’m boes, lenor, dhe’dh ty smagya 107 a-dhyworth da propos rag klevs 108 kepar a vyn Duw dhe’n deves dhe voel bos.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
109 Non attender la forma del martìre: 110 pensa la succession; pensa ch’al peggio 111 oltre la gran sentenza non può ire.
query.result:
**English:**
109 Do not dwell on the form of the punishment: 110 think of the consequences; think that the worst 111 cannot go beyond the great judgment.
**Cornish:**
109 Na attend an furv a’n mersirians: 110 meury an sequiens; meury dhe’n gwaeth 111 owth dhe’n vràs breus na yll mos.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
112 Io cominciai: «Maestro, quel ch’io veggio 113 muovere a noi, non mi sembian persone, 114 e non so che, sì nel veder vaneggio».
query.result:
**English:**
112 I began: “Master, those things that I see 113 moving towards us do not seem like people to me, 114 and I do not know what they are, so I am bewildered by what I see”.
**Cornish:**
112 Y’m kyrhas: “Mester, an tra ow’m gweles 113 ow mosva dhe’n, nyns eus yns kepar dusma, 114 ha nyns ow kov, kepar ow’m gweles yns gwaneth.”

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
115 Ed elli a me: «La grave condizione 116 di lor tormento a terra li rannicchia, 117 sì che ’ miei occhi pria n’ebber tencione.
query.result:
**English:**
115 And he to me: "The grievous condition 116 of their torment on the ground crouches them down, 117 so that my eyes had a dispute about it first."
**Cornish:**
115 Ha henna dhymm: "An sevell golon 116 a'ga boenans orth an nor a's gorra, 117 wosa'm lagha kyns dhe vesa kynsa."

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
118 Ma guarda fiso là, e disviticchia 119 col viso quel che vien sotto a quei sassi: 120 già scorger puoi come ciascun si picchia».
query.result:
**English:**
118 But look intently there, and with your face 119 uncover what comes beneath those rocks: 120 now you can see how each one beats himself."
**Cornish:**
118 Mes gwel yn fast ena, ha diskudh 119 gans dha drog an peth a dheuth a-woles an mein: 120 nyns yu gweles py fenten a'n darav an golon.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
121 O superbi cristian, miseri lassi, 122 che, de la vista de la mente infermi, 123 fidanza avete ne’ retrosi passi,
124 non v’accorgete voi che noi siam vermi 125 nati a formar l’angelica farfalla, 126 che vola a la giustizia sanza schermi?
127 Di che l’animo vostro in alto galla, 128 poi siete quasi antomata in difetto, 129 sì come vermo in cui formazion falla?
130 Come per sostentar solaio o tetto, 131 per mensola talvolta una figura 132 si vede giugner le ginocchia al petto,
133 la qual fa del non ver vera rancura 134 nascere ’n chi la vede; così fatti 135 vid’ io color, quando puosi ben cura.
query.result:
**English:**
121 O proud Christians, wretched and weary, 122 who, sick in the sight of your mind, 123 have trust in backward steps,
124 do you not realize that we are worms 125 born to form the angelic butterfly, 126 that flies to justice without barriers?
127 Why does your soul float on high, 128 then you are almost like an automaton in defect, 129 like a worm in which formation fails?
130 As to support a ceiling or roof, 131 sometimes a figure is seen as a bracket 132 joining its knees to its chest,
133 which makes a false sorrow 134 arise in the one who sees it; thus 135 I saw them, when I paid close attention.
**Cornish:**
121 O kresen Kristyon, meskin ha difethys, 122 neb, klav dhe'n golon, 123 yma fydh yn aga passys golghys,
124 ha'n welowgh nag eus ow tos ni prednow 125 genys dhe furvell a'n ebron, 126 neb a hedha dhe'n jystyans heb lettyans?
127 Dres hemma'n aga enevalow yn uhella, 128 ena yns yw avel onan heb golon, 129 avel prednow neb a'n furvell yw kolla?
130 Avel dhe dhrehevel soler po tyller, 131 a-ugher, onan a weler 132 ow junya aga lin dhe'n brust,
133 neb a wra dhe'n fals ranngas 134 dhe'n neb a'n gwelo; ha'n keth poos 135 y'm gweles aga, pan wrugof vyth fast.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
136 Vero è che più e meno eran contratti 137 secondo ch’avien più e meno a dosso; 138 e qual più pazïenza avea ne li atti,
139 piangendo parea dicer: ‘Più non posso’.
query.result:
**English:**
136 It is true that more and less they were contracted 137 according to how much or little they had on their backs; 138 and whoever had more patience in his actions,
139 weeping seemed to say: ‘I can do no more’.
**Cornish:**
136 Gwir yw moy ha le moy o kontrattas 137 herwydh aga o dassa moy po le moy; 138 ha neb o dassa moy pasyans yn aga oberow,
139 ow weli ow leverel: ‘Nyns yw possyf moy’.
